intro: Lycianthes acapulcensis, commonly known as the Acapulco nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Central America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes tomatoes, potatoes, and peppers. The plant typically grows as an upright shrub with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually yellow or white, and it produces small, berry-like fruits that are edible but contain toxic compounds. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal potential, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
